name: Savannah
fun_fact: Savannah has 22 historic squares draped in Spanish moss-covered live oak trees, and Forrest Gump's famous bench scene was filmed at Chippewa Square. The city also claims the most beautiful street in America (Jones Street) and is home to North America's oldest Black church.

hero_dishes.name: Lowcountry She-Crab Soup
hero_dishes.description: Rich, creamy bisque made with blue crab meat, crab roe, and a touch of sherry
hero_dishes.origin_story: This coastal Georgia specialty has the perfect balance of cream, flavor, and large clumps of fresh crab meat. The 'she' refers to female crabs with roe, which adds richness.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Olde Pink House is famous for possibly the best She-Crab soup you'll ever have

hero_dishes.name: Southern Fried Chicken (Family-Style)
hero_dishes.description: Classic Southern fried chicken served family-style at communal tables with cornbread dressing, sweet potato soufflÃ©, black-eyed peas, okra gumbo
hero_dishes.origin_story: Mrs. Wilkes Dining Room has been serving this tradition since the 1940s - strangers sit together at tables-for-ten with platters passed around
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mrs. Wilkes Dining Room (107 West Jones Street) - line forms at 11am daily

hero_dishes.name: Shrimp and Grits
hero_dishes.description: Perfectly-flaky golden fried shrimp served over creamy stone-ground grits with bacon and gravy
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Lowcountry staple represents Savannah's coastal heritage, combining fresh Georgia shrimp with Carolina grits
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Crystal Beer Parlor, B. Matthew's Eatery, and The Wyld serve exceptional versions

hero_dishes.name: Fried Green Tomatoes
hero_dishes.description: Cornmeal-crusted unripe tomatoes fried golden and crispy, often served with remoulade
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Southern classic that uses end-of-season green tomatoes, popularized by the novel and film of the same name
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Found at most traditional Southern restaurants including The Lady & Sons

signature_drinks.name: Sweet Tea
signature_drinks.description: Ice-cold black tea heavily sweetened while hot, served over ice
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Southerners call it 'the house wine of the South' - it's everywhere and expected to be sweet unless you specify 'unsweet'

signature_drinks.name: Chatham Artillery Punch
signature_drinks.description: Legendary Savannah punch mixing rum, brandy, whiskey, champagne, and fruit juices
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Deceptively strong historical punch dating back to the 1800s - one glass is plenty for most people

food_culture_notes: Family-style dining is huge - Mrs. Wilkes seats strangers together at communal tables
The Grey (in a restored 1938 Greyhound bus terminal) won James Beard awards for chef Mashama Bailey's African-influenced Southern cuisine
Dinner starts late by Southern standards but earlier than European - most restaurants get busy around 6-7pm
Spanish moss and live oak trees create the iconic romantic atmosphere
Savannah is surprisingly affordable - quality Southern meals can be found for under $20

landmarks: 22 historic squares with live oak trees and Spanish moss
Forsyth Park with its iconic fountain (dyed green on St. Patrick's Day)
The Olde Pink House (18th century mansion)
Wormsloe Historic Site with 1.5-mile oak tree tunnel
River Street along the Savannah River
Bonaventure Cemetery with Spanish moss-draped graves
atmosphere: Romantic Southern Gothic ambiance with Spanish moss
Humid subtropical climate with lush greenery
colors: Pastel historic buildings (especially the pink house)
unique_modern: The Grey restaurant in restored Art Deco Greyhound bus terminal
Food tours combining history and gastronomy
Craft cocktail scene in historic settings
